replies.body: Permabans are a punishment, not a free name change.

because releveling is free.
because paying $1500+ per account for skins is "free."
because ever added skin content like little legends is "free."

I do agree that permabans should be permanent.
What I disagree on: Riot's threshold for what deserves a permanent ban.

We all are both toxic players and people who are recipients of toxicity. But that's online gaming and ANY competitive play.

Race baiting/homophobia/hate messages/threats? Sure. Ban that.

Saying "GG" or "OMFG" or calling people "nubs?" Or calling people inters? Just saying "End game:" Softcore insults on a player level? No. Just no. 

------------------

The only reason Riot has gotten away with this autofeedback system was because we're all addicted, and will spend forever, more or less. 

We are all salivating for the next skin, and Hextech Chests opened the floodgates to bring in those who were free players as well..... simply by offering plenty of keys, but not quite enough free Chests to open.

And if we get banned, we just go out and spend another $1500+.... hoping our spouses don't divorce us.

And, ofc .... before you quote the good old .006% are "bad enough to deserve perma ban level of treatment:"

1) stats don't stay stagnant for 6 years. They change.
2) That stat would imply one person per 186,333 is toxic enough to be banned. Anyone who looks at their schools/communities/bars/social events would know that low of a statistic is just an impossible fiction.

It was a number designed for behavior shaming. Nothing more.

Did you read the thread? It's asking for a refund on money spent on a permabanned account. If that were possible, then a permabanned player would simply get all their money back, start a new account, and repurchase everything. The only change would be the user/summoner names. Thus, such a thing would amount to a free name change.

If someone is unable to control themselves on an account they've dumped $1500 into, that's their problem. Literally, a problem. A big one. But it's theirs and no one else's. In cases of "softcore insults," such players always get several punishments before losing the account, with a warning that the final punishment is a permaban and the player is on "thin ice." You don't have to like the rules to follow them. If someone says "no shoes in my house because of the carpets, or I'll kick you out," then you don't wear shoes in their house, even if you think it's a stupid rule because they don't have any carpets. Or you wear shoes and get kicked out.

The statistic isn't about how many players "deserve" a permaban. It's about how many actually get one. There are quite a few players I've seen over the years who should've been severely punished according to Riot's rules but got away with it, including one instance of someone screaming homophobic slurs to "teach us a lesson" while inting to the tune of 0/26 in 18 minutes. No suspension. The system is terrified of false positives (even though there still are false positives sometimes). This kind of behavior _is_ shameful - incredibly so. When someone gets fed off an inting leveling script or something and starts screaming "how are you so bad, lol, ezezezezez" in all chat, do you think that's nice? Do you think their parents would be proud? I think they should feel bad about it. What you call "behavior shaming" is also known as "teaching." This is how people learn what behavior is acceptable and what isn't.

Not only that; in a game where the result of a game can change in 10 seconds, and to where the final objective can take thousands of hours of individually separated micro games invested to achieve. Humans are emotional beings, and are driven by those emotions. There is no avoiding it. (Have you never watched pros stream? Many of them are far more toxic than the people you are condemning, but they get away with it because the culpability in pro play shifts from verbal behavior to actual behavior; In other words, in High elo, you're more likely to get banned for playing Teemo Mid support than you are for being the person who rages and abuses power to attack said Teemo Mid Support (Unless there's a massive social network response that calls BS on it and then Riot responds 2 weeks later to the other person)

> 
> The system is not terrified of false positives. It's an unthinking computer designed to pick up when people use common words associated with bans: You, "Insert name," GG are included in that library. Here's how it works. Unless it picks up a report of "Hate" it simply counts the number of games where you received a report flag versus the number of times the system verified you used keywords.
> 
> -After about 200 verbal flags that have confirmed keywords, you will receive a 5 game chat ban.
> -After about 240 verbal flags that have confirmed keywords, you will receive a 10 game chat ban.
> -Upon receiving and going through a 10 game chat ban, you will be flagged as an urgent account.
> -If you receive another 10 verbal flags in a short period after a 10 game chat ban, you will receive a 2 week account ban.
> -If you complete a 2 week chat ban and receive ANY flags, it will be reviewed by a behavior specialist who then will decide to impose a permanent ban.
> 
> (In other words, you can be perma banned right after a 2 week ban if your first game back resulted in a tragic loss where player decisions cascaded into a loss in front of your eyes, and you react to it).
>

> The reality about parents: Parents are not perfect, and have never been successful at behavior modeling. Otherwise, we'd be a nonwar utopia. They try. And, if they succeed, that does make their child a more productive adult. But that usually doesn't translate into not cussing, not having temper fits, and it certainly doesn't help with mental disorders.

On the internet "tldr" has become synonymous with "summary", depending on the context. Not saying he did read it (how would I know), just saying that's a different way to interpret that line, as well as how I personally interpreted that post.

By adding tldr he's at least dismissing the entire message rather than trying to understand it. Either way, it's hypocritical to say I didn't even read his, when he's dismissive of/didn't read mine.

He threw 4 insults as well, and his temperament easily means he's a reportable in game too. By the impulse of a single post, I'm willing to calculate he's probably reported in at least half of his game, if he doesn't have all chats disabled, and even if he does, he probably re-enables chats just to yell at people.

In other words, he's proving my point: People are human, exhibit bad sportsmanship, and bad sportsmanship isn't and never should be a crime.

What I always find ironic about these posts is that the very people who white knight for perfect behavior themselves show contempt, and throw insults and attempt to put themselves above others..... which is exactly what Bad sportsmanship does. Why does bad sportsmanship happen? Because someone feels themselves superior, and they exhibit contempt for players making mistakes (or even perceived mistakes).

Yes and no. Both parties have some merit and some liability in such a case, and ToS doesn't excuse unconscionable contract.

Riot: Is liable for explaining why they impuned a customer with a punishment after purchases that exceeds the value of the action that received the punishment (In other words, the damages of "1 instance text chats" is far less than say "$2400 in skin purchases." While the behavior may have impuned the fun of a group of players for one game, that is not worth the $2400 in services lost. If a lawsuit went far enough, they could potentially have to explain why they pocketed money for services relinquished that exceed the cost of bad behavior.

Customer: You're right. It is wire fraud. There's not much of getting out of this even if Riot has to explain their side. 

But if a customer didn't commit the fraud, and actually pursued a case against their account ban, they could possibly win some restitution in damages because they would still have a strong case.

(Ofc, if the player made threats or exposed Riot to Liability for some sort of Hate, then their behavior has risen far beyond the level of the purchases, and the ban is absolutely justified)
